abstract.p: Wallse, restaurtant at 344 West 11th Street in Manhattan, offers Austrian-style menu; wall-size mural by Fernand Leger forms backdrop of new Brasserie 8 1/2 restaurant in midtown Manhattan; photo; La Bicyclette opens in Columbus Circle, replacing Delphini; Bar Demi, operated by Verbena on Irving Place, opens on East 17th Street (M)

block.p: Wallse, 344 West 11th Street, is named for Wallsee (pronounced VAHL-zay), a town in Austria where the chef and owner, Kurt Gutenbrunner, was born. The menu is Austrian style, with spatzle and Wiener schnitzel, but not exclusively so.

Wallse, 344 West 11th Street, is named for Wallsee (pronounced VAHL-zay), a town in Austria where the chef and owner, Kurt Gutenbrunner, was born. The menu is Austrian style, with spatzle and Wiener schnitzel, but not exclusively so.

''Les Constructeurs,'' a wall-size mural, the only stained-glass work by Fernand Leger, is the stunning backdrop for Brasserie 8 1/2, on the lower level of 9 West 57th Street. Matisse graphics line the walls. The art is from the collection of Sheldon Solow, the developer who owns the building and the restaurant.

Brasserie 8 1/2, run by Restaurant Associates, is a modern 230-seat room reached by a grand circular staircase. The chef, Julian Alonzo, offers updated brasserie fare, including ceviche and suckling pig.
La Bicyclette has opened at 519 Columbus Avenue (85th Street), replacing Delphini. The chef, Suleyman Farah, is the same, now turning out steak frites.
Verbena, 15 Irving Place (17th Street), has opened Bar Demi, 125 1/2 East 17th Street, in the space that was Verbena to Go. The emphasis is on half bottles of wine, to go with small tasting plates.
